journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency

title-group.article-title: Alcohol Outlets and Community Levels of Interpersonal Violence
title-group.subtitle: Spatial Density, Outlet Type, and Seriousness of Assault

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: William Alex Pridemore is a professor and director of Graduate Studies in the Department of Criminal Justice at Indiana University, where he is also the Associate Director of the Consortium for Education and Social Science Research and an affiliate faculty member of the Russian and East European Institute. His research interests include the effects of social structure on homicide and suicide rates, alcohol epidemiology, and the measurement of crime and deviance.

Tony H. Grubesic is the director of the Geographic Information Systems and Spatial Analysis Laboratory at Drexel University, where he is also an associate professor in the College of Information Science and Technology. His research interests include spatial analysis, GIScience, regional development and public policy.

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Criminal Justice, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, USA
2Geographic Information Systems and Spatial Analysis Laboratory, College of Information Science and Technology, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: William Alex Pridemore, Department of Criminal Justice, Indiana University, 302 Sycamore Hall, Bloomington, IN 47405, USA.. Email: wpridemo@indiana.edu

abstract.p: This study examined the association between alcohol outlets and violence. Employing Cincinnati block groups as units of analysis, the authors estimated spatially lagged regression models to determine if the variation in spatial density of alcohol outlets is related to the spatial density of simple and aggravated assaults. The authors estimated separate models for off-premise outlets, bars, and restaurants. The results revealed a positive and significant association between outlet density and assault density. This association held for simple and aggravated assaults and for total outlet density and the density of each type of outlet. Further tests showed the outlet-violence association to be stronger for off-premise outlets relative to bars and restaurants and for simple relative to aggravated assaults. Estimation of attributable fractions (AFs) showed that off-premise outlets may account for approximately one-quarter and one-third of simple and aggravated assaults, respectively.

body.p: The alcohol-violence association has long been the subject of criminological research (Wolfgang 1958), though studies tend to focus on individuals (Felson et al. 2008) or criminal events (Felson, Burchfield, and Teasdale 2007; Pridemore and Eckhardt 2008). With a few exceptions (e.g., Block and Block 1995; Fagan 1993; Nielsen and Martinez 2003; Parker 1995; Roncek and Maier 1991), ecological studies of alcohol and violence are largely absent from the criminological literature, though in recent years they have increasingly appeared in the journals of other disciplines like epidemiology, public health, and geography (e.g., Britt et al. 2005; Gruenewald et al. 2006; Lipton and Gruenewald 2002; Lipton et al. 2003; Livingston 2008; Pridemore 2002, 2004; Pridemore and Snowden 2009; Zhu, Gorman, and Horel 2004).

While macro-level criminological studies have focused considerable effort on understanding how neighborhood characteristics and context influence crime, they have centered on testing hypotheses generated from social disorganization (Bursik 1988; Sampson and Groves 1989) and related theories like social cohesion (Nieuwbeerta et al. 2008), social capital (Rosenfeld, Messner, and Baumer 2001), and collective efficacy (Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls 1997). More tangible neighborhood characteristics like alcohol outlets have received less attention. Our study examined the association between alcohol outlet density and assault. We contribute to the existing literature in several ways. First, we take into account differing levels of harm using simple and aggravated assaults as dependent variables. Second, we test to see if the strength of association varies by outlet type. Third, we use block groups as our units of analysis, providing a lower level of aggregation than prior studies that employed larger units like ZIP codes, cities, and states. Fourth, we use a different and more spatially appropriate indicator of outlet density. Fifth, we estimate spatially lagged regression models to control for spatial autocorrelation. Finally, we estimate the attributable fraction (AF) for assault due to alcohol outlet density.

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: One reason to expect higher levels of violence where alcohol outlets are concentrated is that greater alcohol availability means more consumption (Blose and Holder 1987) by more people, which will lead to more disputes. This is a compositional argument, not a structural one, though social context may interact with the physiologically disinhibiting effects of alcohol to increase the likelihood of aggression (Giancola, Saucier, and Gussler-Burkhardt 2003; Pihl, Lau, and Assaad 1997). Pernanen (1991) provides detailed conceptual frameworks and theoretical pathways for this relationship, and Parker and Rebhun (1995) outline how alcohol fits into several individual-level criminological theories in a way that will increase violence.

More important to us are the ecological or spatial effects of alcohol outlet density on area violence rates. Disorganization theory leads us to expect higher crime rates in some communities due to neighborhood characteristics, and the same can be said for specific locations within these neighborhoods—street intersections, public transportation nodes, and alcohol outlets (Block and Block 1995; Sherman, Gartin, and Buerger 1989; Stark 1987)—that provide high-risk areas.

Bars and off-premise outlets serve as places where motivated offenders and potential victims converge (Cohen and Felson 1979), especially young males who are at higher risk for offending and victimization. These outlets also may provide permissive settings where norms are ambiguous or supportive of deviant behavior, especially in the context of relaxed inhibitions that occur when drinking. Unkempt areas in and around off-premise alcohol outlets can be a sign that antisocial behavior is less unacceptable in the area. Many view time spent in these places as time-out periods or moral holidays where the normal rules governing interpersonal behavior are weakened (Collins 2008; MacAndrew and Edgerton 1969). According to Parker and Rebhun (1995), weakened normative constraints can interact with consumption to overcome active control over one’s behavior, resulting in selective disinhibition and increasing the likelihood of deviant behavior (Pernanen 1991). The context itself may be enough to overcome constraints, but alcohol’s disinhibiting effect can increase the risk. Thus, the greater the concentration of outlets, the greater the likelihood of places where norms governing behavior might be relaxed.

Research has established bars and clubs as high-risk drinking settings (Macdonald et al. 2005; Stockwell, Lang, and Rydon 1993), and off-premise outlets can also be sources of disorder. Alcohol outlets are heterogeneous, however, and research on bars shows that a wide range of characteristics can affect the amount and seriousness of aggression (Quigley, Leonard, and Collins 2003). For example, Lugo’s (2008) results suggest that the number and density of bars is less important than whether or not bar management promotes irresponsible serving practices and binge drinking. Macintyre and Homel (1997) showed that highly crowded venues were at greater risk for violence and that this crowding was due in part to management decisions about placement of entrances/exits, bathrooms, and other poor choices that had a negative influence on pedestrian flow within the bar. Similarly, Graham and colleagues (Graham, Bernards, et al. 2006; Graham et al. 2005; Graham, Tremblay et al. 2006) discovered several environmental characteristics associated with violence in and around bars, including staff organization, intoxication of patrons, and people remaining around bars after closing. Areas immediately surrounding bars also serve as places where patrons and others hang out (and increasingly go to smoke due to antismoking laws), and social control may be problematic when trading hours for bars are allowed to extend later into the night (Stockwell and Chikritzhs 2009) and when several bars in the same area close at the same time (Humphreys and Eisner 2010).

While the concentration of alcohol outlets in an area is partially the result of socially disorganized neighborhoods (Nielsen et al. 2010), problematic bars and off-premise outlets can themselves contribute to disorganization and decreased social cohesion. According to Stark (1987), we can expect more lenient law enforcement in these types of places, which makes them more attractive for those drawn to crime and deviance. Many off-premise outlets are not simply places where people go to buy alcohol and then leave to take it home with them. Especially in urban areas, these outlets are often convenience stores where people congregate for social interaction. The convenience stores themselves or the spaces immediately surrounding them may serve as de facto taverns (Block and Block 1995) or host other criminal activity such as drug dealing and prostitution (Alaniz, Cartmill, and Parker 1998), thus attracting potential victims and offenders and providing opportunities for violence.

Early research on outlet density and violence provided inconsistent results. Studies by Gorman and colleagues (Gorman, Labouvie et al. 1998; Gorman, Speer et al. 1998) found no association with assault or domestic violence in New Jersey. Block and Block (1995) found no relationship in Chicago, concluding that “[t]he high levels of crime at these locations reflect the crime levels of the surrounding neighborhood more than they reflect a concentration of tavern and liquor store crime” (p. 174). In a follow up to the New Jersey studies, however, Speer et al. (1998) focused on a single city (Newark) and found an association. Using block group data from Washington, DC, Roman et al. (2008) found that on-premise outlets were significantly associated with assaults and that both on- and off-premise outlets were positively associated with disorderly conduct. Studies by Zhu et al. (2004) of Austin and San Antonio census tracts and by Britt et al. (2005) of Minneapolis neighborhoods found a positive association between total outlet density and several violent crimes. In a longitudinal study employing Melbourne, Australia, post codes and estimating fixed effects models, Livingston (2008) found an association between changes in outlet density and changes in assault rates. Finally, in one of the very few analyses appearing in a mainstream criminology journal, Nielsen and Martinez (2003) found an association between total outlets and aggravated assault in Miami census tracts.

We test the hypothesis that the density of all alcohol outlets and of each type of outlet (i.e., off-premise, bar, and restaurant) will be positively associated with the density of total assaults. We also ask two further exploratory research questions. First, if there is an association, does its hold for different levels of harm (i.e., simple versus aggravated assault)? Second, does the strength of any outlet-assault association vary by the outlet type?

sec.title: Unit of analysis
sec.p: Cincinnati, Ohio, was the study area for this analysis. Cincinnati has a population of about 332,000 people. Its violent crime rate of 1,079 per 100,000 residents in 2007 (Federal Bureau of Investigation 2007) was similar to other large cities across the United States, including Pittsburgh (1,107), Sacramento (1,113), Dallas (1,069), Tampa (1,060), and Las Vegas (1,017).

The unit of analysis was the block group. While tracts and ZIP codes have been used in prior studies of outlet density and violence (Gruenewald et al. 2006; Livingston 2008; Zhu et al. 2004), block groups provide a more detailed local snapshot of demographic and socioeconomic structure and are often used for other types of spatial analyses. There is also less potential for aggregation bias when using smaller units like block groups, and there is growing attention being paid in geographic criminology to the theoretical and practical importance of using smaller units like these (see the essays in Weisburd, Bernasco, and Bruinsma 2009). Nationally, block groups average about 40 census blocks and contain 600-3,000 people. There were 302 block groups in our analysis, representing a complete enumeration for Cincinnati, with a mean population of 1,038.

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: Dependent variables were simple and aggravated assault density per square mile. The Cincinnati Police Department provided us with data on all crimes reported to the police between January and June of 2008. Each record included the Uniform Crime Report (UCR) code, time and date of the offense, address, and description of the location (e.g., street, single family house, etc.). We selected simple assaults (n = 2,298) and aggravated assaults (n = 479) for further analysis.1 Assault data were geocoded using the Centrus geocoding engine (Group 1 Software 2008). Only events assigned a street-level match were utilized for analysis, which represents an improvement over previous studies of alcohol outlets and assaults that were forced to utilize data pre-aggregated to census tracts or data geocoded to ZIP codes. Note that these include all assaults and not only assaults that are “alcohol-related,” as police data on the latter are unreliable. Simple assault density in our sample of block groups ranged from 0 (n = 23) to 867 per square mile, with a mean of 69. Aggravated assault density ranged from 0 to 333 per square mile, with a mean of 15. Figure 1A provides a map of Cincinnati block groups with the location of all assaults, and Figure 1B provides a map with block groups shaded by assault density.

caption.p: Spatial distribution of assaults in Cincinnati, Ohio, January to June 2008. A. Simple and aggravated results; B. Total assault density per square mile.

sec.title: Independent variables
sec.p: The main independent variable in this study was alcohol outlet density. We disaggregated this variable into all outlets, off-premise outlets, restaurants, and bars.2 Alcohol outlet data were obtained from the Ohio Division of Liquor Control for Hamilton County, Ohio (ODLC 2008). These data include permit designations that allowed us to disaggregate by outlet type. All outlets with a Cincinnati address were entered into our database. There were 683 unique outlets in Cincinnati during the summer of 2008, and it is common for a single outlet to operate under more than one permit (e.g., C1 and C2). Each outlet was geocoded using the same process described above and aggregated to block groups. The total alcohol outlet density in our sample of block groups ranged from 0 (n = 86) to 545 per square mile, with a mean of 20. Figure 2 provides a map of Cincinnati block groups with the location of the alcohol outlets, with block groups shaded by outlet density.

caption.p: Cincinnati alcohol outlets and outlet density per square mile, 2008.

sec.p: We utilized a measure of spatial density for alcohol outlets and assaults instead of the more traditional per capita measure. That is, the number of outlets and assaults are standardized by the total area of the block groups rather than the number of people living in the unit. There are two compelling reasons, both with theoretical and methodological underpinnings, why this is a stronger framework for spatial-analytical studies of outlet density and violence. Each rests on the fact that when using density measures based on per capita rates, one assumes the distributions of outlets and assaults are functions only of the number of residents in the study area. The first problem is related to the independent variable and is an issue of spatial exposure. Consider two block groups of equal population (1,000) but dramatically different sizes. Unit A is 0.10 square miles and Unit B is 2.5 square miles. Each unit contains 12 alcohol outlets. When using the per capita measurement adjusted to reflect the density of outlets per 100 residents, each unit receives a value of 1.2. While this captures a basic measure of population exposure to outlets, it does not reflect the complexities of spatial proximity to outlets for unit residents. In contrast, when using a measure of spatial density, the scores for each unit are dramatically different, with a value of 120 outlets per square mile for Unit A and 4.8 for Unit B. Our metric provides a more appropriate estimate of spatial exposure and of residential proximity to alcohol outlets.

The second problem is related to the dependent variable and stems from the construction of the numerator and denominator. With a traditional rate-based density metric, the denominator is based on the population living in the block group, with an implicit assumption that victims and offenders of reported assaults live in the block group. This assumption is not reasonable, nor do all block groups contribute victims and offenders equally to nearby block groups. Thus, the numerator in a rate-based measure partially consists of people not included in the denominator. In short, urban residents visit liquor stores and bars and become offenders and victims of assault in block groups in which they do not reside, and thus the resident population cannot be equated with the population at risk. This is no small matter when the mean block group population in our sample is only 1,000 residents. Our spatial measure of assault density overcomes this problem and provides for more accurate comparisons of assaults between block groups, and thus a better gauge of any association between alcohol outlets and assaults.

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: We included several structural characteristics of communities to control for confounding effects. This is important since alcohol outlet density has been shown to be associated with neighborhood characteristics (Nielsen et al. 2010). Our controls included the proportion of the population living below the poverty line, the proportion of the population aged 16 and older that is unemployed, the proportion of households in the block group headed by a female and with a child under the age of 18 years old, the proportion of the population aged 15-24, and the proportion of the population that is African American. We also included a control for population density, given the construction of our main independent and dependent variables. These data were obtained from the Caliper Corporation (2005) and come from the 2000 census.

sec.title: Modeling Framework
sec.p:
We employed spatially lagged regression to examine the effects of alcohol outlets on assaults. Consider the following notation:
β is a k × 1vector of parameters
X is a n × k matrix of exogenous variables
ρ coefficient of spatially lagged dependent variable y
λ coefficient in an error term with a spatial autoregressive structure
μ is a normally distributed error term with a diagonal covariance matrix, Ω
z the diagonal elements of the covariance matrix which are a function of p + 1 exogenous variables, including the constant term
W1 and W2 n × n row standardized weights matricesBoth the general linear regression model and a spatially lagged regression model can be derived from the following general expression (Anselin 1988)1y=ρW1y+Xβ+ϵwhereϵ=λW2ϵ+μ,and μ~N(0,Ω),Ωii=hi(zα)hi>0,In the event of homoscedasticity (α=0) and no spatial dependence in values of the dependent variable (ρ=0) or in the error term (λ=0), Equation (1) simplifies to a standard linear regression model that may be estimated with ordinary least squares (Anselin 1988):2y=Xβ+ϵIf spatial autocorrelation is present in values of the dependent variable but the errors in the variance-covariance matrix are homoscedastic (α=0) and there is no additional spatial autocorrelation in the error term (λ=0), Equation (1) becomes a spatial lag model:3y=ρW1y+Xβ+μ,where μ~N(0,Ω)The value of ρ in this model provides an estimate of the amount of spatial dependence in the values of the dependent variable.

Although ordinary least squares regression has been widely used for assessing the relationship between outlet density and violence, it fails to account for the influence of spatially related data. Geographic units are not always independent of one another (Cliff and Ord 1981; Loftin 1972; Loftin and Ward 1983). Events or processes in one unit often have an impact on events or processes in nearby units. Therefore, the choice of statistical models for examining the impact of outlet density on violence should include the ability to model spatial dependence between units (Britt et al. 2005; Millar and Gruenewald 1997; Zhu et al. 2004).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 provides the results of two global, spatial regression models, both of which use a queen’s contiguity spatial weight matrix for analysis. The first model explores the relationship between simple assaults, total alcohol outlet density, and control variables, while the second provides an identical analysis for aggravated assaults. The R-squared value shows that model 1 explains about 75 percent of the variance in simple assaults, and alcohol outlet density is positively and significantly associated with assault density. The spatial lag (Rho) associated with assault density is a positive and significant contributor to the model, confirming the importance of spatial proximity for capturing the relationships between outlet density and assault. While the overall explanatory power for model 2 is somewhat lower in comparison (R2 = .52), the inferences drawn for outlet density remain the same.

caption.p: Spatial Lag Models for Total Alcohol Outlet Density and Assault Density.

sec.p: Models 3-8 in Tables 2 and 3 were estimated to provide a more nuanced analysis of the relationship between simple and aggravated assaults and alcohol outlet types. Table 2 displays the results when simple assault density was regressed on off-premise outlets (model 3), restaurants (model 4), and bars (model 5). Similar to the global models, the density of each type of outlet was positively and significantly associated with simple assault density. The coefficient in model 3 suggests that an increase in one off-premise outlet per square mile per six months is associated with 2.3 more simple assaults per square mile. Similarly, models 4 and 5 suggest similar effect sizes for restaurants (+ 1.15) and bars (+1.35) on simple assault density. In all three cases, the models explained about 70 percent of the variance in simple assault density.

caption.p: Spatial Lag Models for Simple Assault Density and Outlet Density, by Outlet Type.
Spatial Lag Models for Aggravated Assault Density and Outlet Density, by Outlet Type.

sec.p: Table 3 shows the results when aggravated assault density was regressed on the three different outlet types. The density of off-premise outlets and of restaurants was positively and significantly associated with aggravated assault density, though bar density was not. The overall explanatory power of the models for aggravated assault was lower, explaining about 52 percent of the variance. Once again, however, off-premise establishments have the most notable impact on increasing aggravated assault. Specifically, an increase in one off-premise outlet per square mile per six months was associated with 0.6 more aggravated assaults per square mile.3

Finally, to determine if the positive effect of outlet density for each type of outlet varied by level of harm (i.e., simple relative to aggravated assaults), we tested for equality of regression coefficients between models (Clogg, Petcova, and Haritou 1995:1276; Paternoster et al. 1998). This comparison was undertaken via a z test for the difference between slopes. The equation isz=b1−b2SEb12−SEb22.Obtaining corresponding slope coefficients and standard errors for each outlet type for simple and aggravated assaults, we found that z was significant in all cases, meaning we reject the null hypothesis of equality. In other words, the effect of the density of each type of outlet—off-premise, bars, and restaurants—was stronger for simple assaults than for aggravated assaults.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Research on the alcohol-violence association has focused on individuals and, to a lesser extent, the criminal event. In recent years, however, greater attention has been given to ecological models that have examined the influence of alcohol availability and alcohol outlets on area crime rates. Our results revealed a positive and significant association between total outlet density and total assault density in our sample of Cincinnati block groups. The association held for each type of outlet. This does not mean alcohol outlets are problematic per se, but that their concentration in an area is associated with higher levels of both simple and aggravated assault.

The results also showed that the strength of the outlet-assault association varies by outlet type. The density of off-premise outlets was more strongly related to both simple and aggravated assaults than bars and restaurant density. This is consistent with Gruenewald et al. (2006), who found a stronger association between off-premise outlet density and serious assault, though in their study they found no association with assault for bars or restaurants. While bars provide a place for people to congregate and drink, they also provide a certain level of informal social control via other patrons and semiformal control by bar bouncers and staff (Graham et al. 2005), which can limit the amount and escalation of violent encounters. This could provide a reason behind our most tenuous finding. That is, while our results suggest a positive association between bar density and aggravated assault, the p value does not allow for strong conclusions (though there is a clear association between bar density and simple assault). Off-premise outlets, on the other hand, not only often provide a place for locals to socialize outside the store but largely lack formal social control and provide lower guardianship, especially since most of these outlets are convenience stores or gas stations. This can result in the greater likelihood of a violent event taking place and more easily allows for the escalation of aggression once it begins. If the outlet is, in fact, a place for community members to socialize, it may also serve as the place where ongoing disputes and grievances are resolved, regardless of any role of alcohol.

Higher assault density is not associated solely with the physical space surrounding off-premise outlets. Unlike bars, where alcohol is purchased and consumed under the supervision of bar staff and other security, alcohol purchased at off-premise outlets is consumed largely in homes and other private settings without such guardianship, likely increasing the risk of violent outcomes. Our controls for the usual covariates of neighborhood violence, however, suggest that our finding is not due simply to off-premise outlet density being higher in otherwise high crime neighborhoods (Madensen and Eck 2008, come to the same conclusion about high crime bars).

We also found that the strength of the outlet-violence association was stronger for simple compared to aggravated assaults. This held for all three outlet types. This may have as much to do with the nature of assaults as it does with the alcohol-violence association. Simple assault is a broad category that contains a wide range of low level assaultive behavior, the risk of which likely increases with the consumption of alcohol by one or more of the people involved in the event. On the other hand, while there is evidence of a dose-response relationship between alcohol consumption and aggression (Corrao et al. 1999; Macdonald et al. 2005; Pridemore and Eckhardt 2008; Wells and Graham 2003; Wells, Graham, and West 2000), the different reasons for and relative rarity of serious violence may mean these events, on average, more often result from other causes.

Although not tested directly, our results are consistent with the spatio-temporal notions that some alcohol outlets may be perceived as “deviant places” where patrons expect a “time out” from the normal rules governing interpersonal behavior, including violence. From crowded dance clubs filled with young people in an upscale entertainment district to a convenience store parking lot in a rundown area littered with trash, beer cans, and broken bottles, these are settings where limits on behavior are ambiguous (Nielsen and Martinez 2003) and where intoxication may be more likely to selectively disinhibit people’s choices (Parker and Rebhun 1995).

It may be that outlet density is confounded with other neighborhood characteristics that increase violence (Block and Block 1995). Our analysis and those of others, however, controlled for several structural characteristics commonly found to be associated with higher levels of violence. One may also argue that there is nothing special about alcohol outlets, as they are simply like any other retail outlet that might provide food, clothing, or some service, and thus provide places where a greater concentration of motivated offenders and potential victims come into contact. Yet recent work by Gruenewald et al. (2006) controlled for the density of non-alcohol retail, food, and service establishments and found no association with assault, though the association between outlet density and serious violence remained.

A final consideration is effect size. It might be argued that the magnitude of the effect of alcohol outlets on assault, while statistically significant, was small. An increase of one off-premise outlet per square mile per six months, for example, was associated with 2.3 more simple assaults and 0.6 more aggravated assaults per square mile. However, the mean density of off-premise outlets in these block groups was only 8 per square mile and the mean number of simple and aggravated assaults was 69 and 15 per square mile, respectively. To address this point, we estimate an AF, which in our case would be the expected percent decrease in assaults if all alcohol outlets were removed. While often estimated in ecological and community-level studies in epidemiology, AFs are rarely computed by macro criminologists, probably because the traditional method of deriving an AF is dependent on information about relative risk (RR) computed from individual-level data. However, deriving AFs from aggregate ecological data is a straightforward exercise due to the relationships between the RR, AF, and regression coefficient. For details on both theory and method, the reader is urged to consult Norström (1988a, 1988b). The macro AF is computed asAF=bXY,where b is the effect parameter, X the risk factor (outlet density), and Y the outcome (assault density). Using effect sizes from Tables 2 and 3 and means for off-premise outlet (7.79) and assault density for simple (69.28) and aggravated assaults (14.99), respectively, the AFs for off-premise outlets are 26 percent and 30 percent. In other words, we could expect a reduction of one-quarter in simple assaults and nearly one-third in aggravated assaults in our sample of Cincinnati block groups were alcohol outlets removed entirely. For simple assaults, the corresponding AFs are 10 percent and 12 percent for restaurants and bars. For aggravated assaults, the AFs are 8 percent and 4 percent for restaurants and bars. The AFs for off-premise outlets represent substantial reductions and clearly reveal the impact of alcohol outlet density on assault density in our sample. More generally, while the AF is an extrapolation from the data and must be interpreted with caution, computing and reporting AFs aids in (a) the accumulation of evidence via comparison of AFs from different studies and (b) assessing the plausibility of an estimated macro-level effect.4

sec.title: Limitations of Current Study
sec.p: Two main limitations in our study are associated with the dependent variable. First, we have no way of knowing which assaults included in our measure were alcohol-related (see Livingston 2008) or occurred at an alcohol outlet (see Block and Block 1995). Information about alcohol involvement is sometimes recorded as part of the police record of an event, though the absence of such information does not necessarily mean the event was not alcohol- and/or outlet-associated but only that police did not note it in the record. Second, our assault data depends on police records and thus the traditional limitations associated with them. Nevertheless, if reporting and recording procedures are similar across the units in our analysis, which is likely to be the case for serious violent crimes, then this limitation becomes less troublesome. Using National Crime Victimization Survey data, Baumer (2002) showed that neighborhood disadvantage is not significantly associated with reporting aggravated assault. Baumer did find an association between neighborhood disadvantage and reporting simple assault, however, which must be kept in mind when interpreting our results.

There may also be limitations associated with the set of independent variables included in our models. Most importantly, we were unable to control for actual alcohol sales or alcohol consumption within block groups.5 Similarly, we did not control for land use or other area characteristics that might be associated with heightened levels of violence, such as major intersections, public transportation nodes, illegal drug trade, and nighttime business centers (Block and Block 1995; Gruenewald et al. 2006; Roncek and Maier 1991).

sec.title: General Policy Implications
sec.p: Ecological explanations like collective efficacy, social disorganization, and social cohesion are consistently found to be associated with area violence rates. Yet most elements of these theories—poverty, ethnic heterogeneity, residential mobility, anonymity of community members, and willingness to intervene on others' behalf—are notoriously difficult to remedy via policy or other social mechanisms. Alcohol outlet density, on the other hand, is more amenable to policy changes (Livingston, Chikritzhs, and Room 2007). The concentration of off-premise alcohol outlets can be reduced by limiting liquor permits, setting density thresholds, requiring new outlets to be outside some minimum distance from existing outlets, refusing to issue a new license when a former alcohol outlet has gone out of business (especially if the area already possesses problematic outlets or a high density of outlets), and limiting outlets in high risk areas such as socially disorganized communities and neighborhoods with a high concentration of college students. Liquor licensing boards can close outlets that have proven to be a public nuisance via repeatedly violating liquor laws or being a hot spot for crime. We know from the empirical literature on bars that alcohol-related problems are not distributed equally among bars and that management decisions and business practices are partly to blame. Similarly, we can identify the characteristics of high crime off-premise outlets and (a) encourage management to make more responsible decisions (Madensen and Eck 2008) and (b) target limited public resources on improving or eliminating these risky facilities (Eck, Clarke, and Guerette 2007).

Unlike other negative neighborhood characteristics that often seem intractable, regulating the density and management of alcohol outlets, especially off-premise outlets, can be more readily addressed with a mixture of policies by liquor licensing boards, police, and government agencies that regulate land use. These and other alcohol policies can promote responsible business practices and responsible drinking, and improve the quality of life in communities by limiting deviant places and reducing violence and other alcohol-related problems within neighborhoods. By doing so, such actions could even help promote local levels of social organization, social cohesion, and collective efficacy.

sec.title: Avenues for Future Research by Criminologists on the Outlet-Violence Association
sec.p: Our results, together with those of other criminologists (Nielsen and Martinez 2003; Parker, Luter, and Murphy 2007) and those from public health and epidemiology (e.g., Gorman et al. 2001; Gruenewald et al. 2006; Livingston 2008) suggest a prominent role for alcohol in the study of the social ecology of crime.

First, we must answer a more general question posed by Sherman et al. (1989:46) about hot spots of criminality. That is, do alcohol outlets “vary in their capacity to help cause crime, or merely in their frequency of hosting crime that was going to occur some place inevitably, regardless of the specific place?” So, are alcohol outlets simply hosts or might outlets cause crime and thus result in a higher rate than would exist were they not there? If it is the latter, then one avenue of further research is to go beyond current analyses of outlet density that treat all outlets the same. There is substantial research on this topic for bars and clubs, but little similar research on off-premise outlets, which our results suggest play an important role in community levels of assault. Even given similar outlet type (e.g., off-premise), outlets vary on a number of characteristics. Do hours of opening and closing play a role in violence? What about the amount of alcohol sales or the number of patrons? We need to know more about the specific characteristics of alcohol outlets that contribute to their association with violence. Thus, we agree with Graham (2006:620) that “[w]e need a better understanding of what actually occurs in and around off-premise alcohol outlets that might account for the relationship with violence.” Research on off-premise outlets should follow that on bars in order to identify why some outlets are more responsible for violence than others, and if some of these characteristics can be remedied via manager decision making (Madensen and Eck 2008). Who are the clientele of these outlets? Is it a convenience store or a more traditional liquor store? Is it a place where people come to buy liquor and leave, or does it serve as a social gathering spot? Is it located on a major road or intersection, or perhaps in a strip mall, or in a storefront on an urban block? How are the premises and local environment kept up physically, both inside and out? Is it clean, well lit, and well-cared for, or run down and dirty, with trash or empty bottles and cans around the building or in the gutter? Outlets will vary on these physical, environmental, and situational characteristics, which we can expect to play a role in their risk for contributing to problem behavior (Eck, Clarke, and Guerette 2007). Answering these questions goes beyond merely examining density (Lugo 2008) but requires more systematic social observation of public spaces (Sampson and Raudenbush 1999) inside and out, including the type (though obviously adapted to fit off-premise outlets) of detailed observation of the bar milieu carried out by Graham and colleagues (e.g., Graham, Bernards et al. 2006; Graham et al. 2005; Graham, Osgood et al. 2006; Graham, Tremblay et al. 2006; see also Homel and Clark 1994; Lugo 2008).

Second, some research on alcohol outlets and crime should employ longitudinal analysis. While cross-sectional studies such as ours are informative, it is important to understand how changes in outlet density influence changes in local violence rates. This can be done via change scores for both or, if data are available, by employing a panel design that takes into account changes in outlet density and assault (see Gruenewald and Remer 2006; Livingston 2008). Similarly, criminologists can employ interrupted time series analysis to take advantage of natural experiments. What happens, for example, when a new alcohol policy is implemented that alters the conditions of alcohol sales (Humphreys and Eisner 2010; Pridemore and Snowden 2009)?

Third, it is vital that we better understand the role of neighborhood characteristics in the outlet-violence association. It is clear from the literature that many scholars assume that a greater concentration of outlets just reflects greater neighborhood disorganization. Is the relationship really this simple? For example, does a high concentration of bars and clubs in an entertainment district result from disorganization or organization? Are all alcohol outlets unwanted and viewed with derision by a majority of the community? It is likely that these associations are more complex and equally likely that the effects of outlet density on violence vary by place and by type of neighborhood. It could be, for example, that alcohol outlets partially mediate the association between disorganization and violence. Interaction effects may also play a role (Gruenewald et al. 2006; Peterson, Krivo, and Harris 2000; Zhu et al. 2004). Might high levels of organization or collective efficacy buffer the effect of high outlet density on violence? Similarly, disorganized communities may be more susceptible to the negative effects of alcohol outlets, even if the latter are not highly concentrated in the area. Interaction effects with land use are also important to examine. Is the outlet-violence association moderated by the prevailing land use in the area? Or by being located near vacant parcels, public transportation nodes, or in a manufacturing or warehouse district? It is difficult to imagine that the spatial effects of alcohol outlets on violence do not vary by location, requiring that we examine more closely any contextual effects represented by neighborhood and land use characteristics.

Finally, there are important methodological questions to consider when examining the effects of alcohol outlets on violence from a spatial perspective. For example, if one is interested in exploring the role of land use in the outlet-violence association, how is spatial proximity best captured? Murray and Roncek (2008) utilized both a queen’s contiguity measure and a “radial” distance (i.e., Euclidean) buffer of 500 feet for capturing adjacency. The radial Euclidean distance measure is a relatively poor surrogate for spatial proximity because both offenders and victims traverse urban environments along a street network. As a result, when using Euclidean distance to capture spatial proximity, one may overestimate these proximity relationships. Therefore, we need to consider more theoretically appropriate alternative measures, and the geography literature can provide assistance here.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Relative to abstract concepts like social disorganization and its variants, the mainstream criminological literature on social ecology and crime rates has paid little attention to tangible ecological characteristics that may influence violence rates. One characteristic that has been the topic of recent research in the epidemiology, public health, and geography literatures, however, is alcohol outlet density. We employed a more spatially appropriate measure of community alcohol outlet density, used smaller units of analysis that allow for greater resolution of community characteristics and thus are more theoretically and practically appropriate, controlled for spatial autocorrelation, examine various types of alcohol outlets to determine their differential effects on community violence, and computed AFs. Using Cincinnati block groups as our unit of analysis and simple and aggravated assaults as our dependent variables, we found a general pattern of association between outlet density and assault density. We also found that while the associations held for both simple and aggravated assaults, the association with simple assaults was stronger. Finally, for both simple and aggravated assaults, we found that the strength of the association with violence was significantly greater for off-premise outlets than for bars and restaurants.

In sum, alcohol outlet density appears to play an important role in community violence rates, and the strength of this association varies by outlet type. While alcohol consumption may have individual-level effects on violent offending and victimization, our results provide evidence of ecological effects. Our research has direct policy implications, reveals the promise of the application of geographic information system and spatial analysis to the study of alcohol and violence, and presents clear avenues for future analysis of the outlet-violence association. Although other disciplines have paid more empirical attention to this association, too often public health and epidemiological research is conducted independent of theoretical frameworks suitable for understanding the social processes that underlie violence, thus neglecting important theoretical concerns that could direct empirical inquiry. We believe criminology can be beneficial in this respect, and our findings should encourage further criminological and sociological investigation of the nature of the ecological association between alcohol and violence.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article: This research was partially supported by Indiana University’s Faculty Research Support Program and administered by the Office of the Vice Provost for Research.

The UCR defines simple assaults as those that do not involve a firearm, knife, cutting instrument, or other dangerous weapon, and in which the victim did not sustain serious injuries. The UCR defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. These assaults are usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm.

For our purposes, off-premise outlets were those with C1, C2, and C2X licenses, restaurants were D1, D2, and D2X, and bars were D3, D5, and D6. In Ohio, liquor and grocery stores that sell spirits have no Number-Letter license but instead are referred to as “liquor agencies” and go through a different application process. There are 14 of these in Cincinnati and we counted them as “off-premise.” As a sensitivity check, we removed them and reestimated the effects of off-premise outlets. While the effect size was slightly changed, the inferences remained the same.

To disentangle confounding relationships between outlet types, we estimated models that controlled for multiple outlet types. The association between off-premise outlets and assault held even after including controls for bar and restaurant density. However, when controlling for off-premise outlet density, assault density was not significantly associated with either bar or restaurant density. These supplemental results are available from the authors.

In sensitivity analyses, one can compute an AF to ensure the parameter is not implausibly large or small. Similarly, one can usually compute an AF from the information reported in published articles to do the same thing. See Norström (1988b:340) for a clear example of the latter.

We note, however, that a prior study (Stevenson, Lind, and Weatherburn 1999) found that a significant association between off-premise outlets and violence remained after controlling for alcohol sales.
